name: Tomato (bush/determinate)
protection: Fleece on cold nights; greenhouse in N Scotland
tips: Start indoors, harden off; feed high potash from first truss; even watering to avoid split/BER.
notes: Choose early outdoor types in Scotland (e.g., 'Stupice', 'Outdoor Girl'). Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Tomato (cordon/indeterminate)
spacing: Single stem to cane; 40–50cm between plants
tips: Pot-on progressively; remove side shoots; tie in; consistent water; vent to reduce blight risk.
notes: Later but heavier crop under cover. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Tomato (cherry)
protection: Fleece early; cover from prolonged rain.
tips: Great for baskets; keep fed and picked.
notes: Early and reliable in cool summers. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Pepper (sweet/bell)
tips: Start early and keep warm (20–25°C germination). Stake as fruit sets; feed high potash.
notes: Compact early varieties do best (e.g., 'Gypsy', 'Ace'). Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Chilli Pepper
where: Greenhouse, windowsill, patio in warm spells
protection: Greenhouse; fleece at night early/late season.
tips: Start very early for good ripening; bottom heat helps; don’t overwater; pick to encourage set.
notes: Many chillies colour late—prioritise early cultivars in Scotland. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Aubergine (eggplant)
tips: Start early with heat; focus on small-fruited types; hand-pollinate flowers if needed.
notes: Marginal outdoors—under cover strongly advised. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Okra (lady’s finger) – experimental
tips: Choose compact early cultivars; grow only in reliably warm microclimates.
notes: Challenging in Scotland; greenhouse only. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Cucumber (greenhouse)
tips: Train up twine; keep evenly moist; avoid wetting leaves; pick regularly.
notes: Choose parthenocarpic greenhouse types (all-female). Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Cucumber (ridge/outdoor)
tips: Harden off well; grow on a wigwam or trellis; mulch to conserve moisture.
notes: Short-season varieties best outdoors in Scotland. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Gherkin (pickling cucumber)
tips: Harvest small and often for crisp pickles; train to support.
notes: Prolific in pots with support. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Courgette
tips: Feed and water generously; harvest very young fruits to keep plant productive.
notes: Compact/bush cultivars are ideal for pots.

name: Marrow
tips: Similar to courgette but allow fruits to mature; strong feeding required.
notes: Space-hungry; consider vertical training if possible.

name: Winter Squash (butternut)
tips: Mulch; train vines; cure fruits in sun post-harvest.
notes: Needs the warmest microclimate; choose early cultivars. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Winter Squash (acorn/kabocha)
tips: Earlier than butternut; compact vines suit pots better.
notes: Reliable set in shorter seasons compared to butternut. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Summer Squash (patty pan)
tips: Harvest small and often for best texture.
notes: Good patio crop with steady feeding. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Pumpkin (small varieties)
tips: Limit fruits per plant to ripen; feed heavily.
notes: Choose small/mini types for Scotland (e.g., 'Jack Be Little').

name: Melon (greenhouse, small-fruited)
protection: Consistent warmth; pollinate if not parthenocarpic.
tips: Train on trellis; sling fruits; maintain humidity but ventilate.
notes: Select fast, small-fruited types e.g., 'Minnesota Midget'. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Watermelon (mini, greenhouse)
tips: Graft or choose ultra-early minis; use thermal mass; limit fruit set.
notes: Experimental in Scotland; feasible under heat. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Cucamelon (Mexican sour gherkin)
tips: Vigorous climber; pick small for best crunch.
notes: Tolerant and productive in containers. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Tomatillo
protection: Fleece early; needs two plants for pollination.
tips: Grow at least two plants; stake; harvest when husks split.
notes: Great for salsas; tolerates cooler summers better than tomatoes.

name: Ground Cherry (Cape Gooseberry/Physalis)
tips: Grows like a small tomato; fruit drops when ripe; store in husk.
notes: Ripens late—start early under heat. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Pea (sugar snap)
tips: Soak seed if cold; succession sow; keep cool roots.
notes: Compact varieties suit containers; harvest pods young.

name: Pea (mangetout)
tips: Pick flat pods early; keep evenly moist.
notes: Good cool-weather crop for Scotland.

name: French Bean (dwarf/bush)
tips: Warm soil before sowing; pick often for continuous set.
notes: Choose dwarf types for exposed sites.

name: French Bean (climbing)
tips: Train up canes; keep watered in flower.
notes: Longer season than dwarf but needs shelter.

name: Runner Bean
protection: Wind shelter; mulch to retain moisture.
tips: Excellent in cool summers; attract pollinators; mist flowers in heat.
notes: Good performer in Scotland vs French beans in cooler seasons.

name: Sweetcorn (mini/early)
tips: Grow in blocks for pollination (at least 9 plants); keep well watered.
notes: Choose ultra-early types (e.g., 'Swift', 'Earlybird').

name: Mini-corn (baby corn)
tips: Harvest immature cobs; fewer heat requirements; reliable.
notes: Easier than sweetcorn to ripen in Scotland.

name: Rhubarb (forced/containers)
protection: Mulch; protect crown in severe frost.
tips: Do not harvest first year; feed well; can be forced for early stems.
notes: Technically vegetable; used as fruit. Hardy and dependable.

name: Spaghetti Squash
tips: Train vines; cure fruits after harvest.
notes: Shorter season than some pumpkins; feasible under good summer. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.

name: Bottle Gourd (calabash) – experimental
tips: Treat like squash; long season needed.
notes: Grown for novelty; culinary use when young. Generally fine outdoors in warm, sheltered spots across England.
